courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: The Beauty of Kunqu Opera
courses.description: This course introduces students to the music, performance, literature and aesthetics of Kunqu opera in order to enhance their understanding of traditional Chinese culture, classical Chinese literature as well as performing arts. Selected scenes from Kunqu classics, such as The Peony Pavilion and The Palace of Eternal Youth will be analyzed and discussed before they are staged for appreciation. Under the teachers’ guidance, students will be able to experience the unity of song and dance as well as the artistic expression of emotions in the world of Kunqu opera.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to:

1. reflect on the relationship between the Chinese cultural heritage and the modern society;
2. analyze the meaning of Kunqu classical texts as well as the characteristics of their performances;
3. create new art works by way of integrating traditional cultural resources with contemporary aesthetic experiences.

通過本課程的學習，學生將能夠 :

1. 反省中國文化傳統與現代社會的關係；

2. 分析崑曲經典文本的意義與表演的特質；

3. 結合傳統的文化資源與當代的審美經驗，創作新的藝術作品。
courses.course_syllabus:
本科共分五個單元:

| **單元一：歷史文化視野中的崑曲** | **上課時數** |
| --- | --- |
| 1. 崑曲演出簡史 | 2 |
| 2. 崑曲與明清歷史社會 | 2 |
| **單元二：崑曲的音樂** | |
| 3. 崑腔音樂 | 2 |
| 4. 崑唱藝術 | 2 |
| **單元三：崑曲與古典文學** | |
| 5. 崑曲經典劇目 | 2 |
| **單元四：崑曲的表演藝術** | |
| 6. 崑曲巾生、小官生的表演藝術 | 2 |
| 7. 崑曲大官生、窮生的表演藝術 | 2 |
| 8. 崑曲閨門旦、正旦及老生的表演藝術 | 2 |
| 9. 崑曲淨行及武生的表演藝術 | 2 |
| 10. 崑曲貼旦與丑行的表演藝術 | 2 |
| **單元五：崑曲美學與現代世界** | |
| 11. 崑曲詩的意境：從平面到立體 | 2 |
| 12. 崑曲新美學：傳統與現代 | 2 |
| 13. 課程總結：崑曲與現代世界 | 2 |

The course consists of 5 modules:

| **Module 1. *Kunqu* in the Historical, Cultural Perspective** | Hours |
| --- | --- |
| 1. A Brief History of *Kunqu* Performance | 2 |
| 2. *Kunqu* and Society in Ming and Qing Dynasties | 2 |
| **Module 2. *Kunqu* Music** | |
| 3. Music of *Kunqu* tunes | 2 |
| 4. Singing of *Kunqu* | 2 |
| **Module 3. *Kunqu* and Classical Literature** | |
| 5. Classical *Kunqu* Pieces | 2 |
| **Module 4. Performing Arts of *Kunqu*** | |
| 6. *Kunqu* Performance [*jinsheng* 巾生] | 2 |
| 7. *Kunqu* Performance [*guansheng*冠生, *qiongsheng*窮生] | 2 |
| 8. *Kunqu* Performance [g*uimen dan*閨門旦, *zhengdan* 正旦, *laosheng* 老生] | 2 |
| 9. *Kunqu* Performance [*jing*淨, *wusheng*武生] | 2 |
| 10. *Kunqu* Performance [*tiedan* 貼旦, *chou* 丑] | 2 |
| **Module 5. Aesthetics of *Kunqu* and the Modern World** | |
| 11. The Lyrical and Artistic Conception of *Kunqu*: from Text to Performance | 2 |
| 12. New Aesthetics of *Kunqu*: Tradition in the Modern Era | 2 |
| 13. Finale: *Kunqu* and the Modern World | 2 |
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey
2. Internal Course Review
courses.required_readings:
一、崑曲演出簡史

1. 王安祈：〈驚春誰似我〉（講者提供）
2. 王安祈：〈「臺灣的崑劇效應」與「崑劇的臺灣效應」〉（講者提供）
3. 胡忌：〈崑劇概述〉，《中國戲曲精編‧崑劇卷》，上海：上海聲像讀物出版社，1989年，頁1-9。

二、崑曲與明清歷史社會

1. 周育德︰《崑曲與明清社會》，瀋陽︰春風文藝出版社，2005年，頁18-30；頁124-136。

三、崑腔音樂

1. 周秦︰《蘇州崑曲》，蘇州︰蘇州大學出版社，2004年，頁36-69。
2. 辛清華：〈崑劇音樂〉，《中國戲曲精編‧崑劇卷》，上海：上海聲像讀物出版社，1989年，頁38-44。

四、崑唱藝術

1. 王家熙、許寅等整理︰〈習曲要解〉，《俞振飛藝術論集》，上海︰上海文藝出版社，1985年，頁323-362。
2. 吳新雷︰〈論崑曲藝術中的「俞派唱法」〉，《中國戲曲史論》，南京︰江蘇教育出版社，1996年，頁340-351。

五、崑曲經典劇目

1. 高明：《琵琶記‧吃糠》，《綴白裘》第十二集，北京：中華書局，2005年。
2. 湯顯祖︰《牡丹亭‧遊園驚夢》，《綴白裘》第四集，北京：中華書局，2005年。
3. 洪昇原著，竹村則行、康保成箋注︰《長生殿‧哭像》，鄭州︰中州古籍出版社，1999年，頁226-236。

六、崑曲巾生、小官生的表演藝術

1. 湯顯祖：《牡丹亭．拾畫》，《綴白裘》第一集，北京：中華書局，2005年。
2. 佚名：《牧羊記．望鄉》，《粟廬曲譜》，台北︰中華民俗藝術基金會，1996年，頁369-394。
3. 岳美緹︰〈崑劇巾生表演的藝術特點〉，《巾生今世──岳美緹崑曲五十年》，北京，文化藝術出版社，2008年，頁271-306。

七、崑曲大官生、窮生的表演藝術

1. 佚名：《綵樓記．潑粥》，《綴白裘》第四集，北京：中華書局，2005年。
2. 謝柏梁、鈕君怡︰《雅部正音—官生魁首》，上海︰上海古籍出版社，2012年，頁73-77。

八、崑曲閨門旦、正旦及老生的表演藝術

1. 湯顯祖：《牡丹亭．尋夢》，《綴白裘》第四集，北京：中華書局，2005年。
2. 佚名：《爛柯山．前逼．後逼》，《崑戲集存》甲編卷六，合肥︰黃山書社，2011年，頁4603-4624。
3. 阿甲︰〈從崑劇《爛柯山》談張繼青的表演藝術——兼談生活體驗和戲曲舞臺體驗的關係問題〉，中國崑劇研究會編︰《張繼青表演藝術》，南京︰江蘇人民出版社，1993年，頁21-38。

九、崑曲淨行及武生的表演藝術

1. 關漢卿：《關大王獨赴單刀會》，《綴白裘》第一集，北京：中華書局，2005年。
2. 李開先：《寶劍記．夜奔》，《崑戲集存》甲編卷二，合肥︰黃山書社，2011年，頁1397-1406。
3. 侯永奎︰〈談《單刀會》〉，侯少奎、胡明明︰《大武生——侯少奎崑曲五十年》，北京︰文化藝術出版社，2007年，頁384-292。
4. 侯少奎、胡明明：〈崑曲《單刀會‧刀會》關羽表演詳解〉，《大武生——侯少奎崑曲五十年》，北京︰文化藝術出版社，2007年，頁193-206。

十、崑曲貼旦與丑行的表演藝術

1. 佚名：《孽海記．思凡下山》，《崑戲集存》甲編卷六，合肥︰黃山書社，2011年，頁4899-4940。
2. 華傳浩︰〈談《下山》〉，《我演崑丑》，上海︰上海文藝出版社，1961年，頁129-145。

十一、崑曲詩的意境：從平面到立體

1. 白先勇：〈我的崑曲之旅〉，收入白先勇：《白先勇作品集IX：青春版牡丹亭》，臺北：天下遠見出版股份有限公司，2008年，頁10-23。
2. 白先勇：〈驚變──記上海崑劇團《長生殿》的演出〉，收入白先勇：《白先勇作品集IX：青春版牡丹亭》，臺北：天下遠見出版股份有限公司，2008年，頁24-35。

十二、崑曲新美學：傳統與現代

1. 潘星華：〈一個是「美」，一個是「情」──白先勇訪談錄〉，收入白先勇：《白先勇作品集IX：青春版牡丹亭》，臺北：天下遠見出版股份有限公司，2008年，頁344-374。
2. 白先勇、吳新雷對談：〈全球化時代崑曲的發展——白先勇vs.吳新雷〉，收入白先勇：《白先勇作品集IX：青春版牡丹亭》，臺北：天下遠見出版股份有限公司，2008年，頁375-416。
courses.recommended_readings:
1. 吳新雷主編：《崑曲藝術概論》，太原：山西教育出版社，2011年。

2. 吳新雷、朱棟霖：《中國崑曲藝術》，南京：江蘇教育出版社，2004年。

3. 李曉：《中國崑曲》，上海：百家出版社，2004年。

4. 鄭雷：《崑曲》，杭州：浙江人民出版社，2005年。

5. 劉靜：《幽蘭飄香：崑曲之美》，北京：紫禁城出版社，2009年。

6. 周育德：《崑曲與明清社會》，瀋陽：春風文藝出版社，2005年。

7. 劉禎、謝雍君：《崑曲與文人文化》，瀋陽：春風文藝出版社，2005年。

8. 陸萼庭：《崑劇演出史稿》，上海：上海教育出版社，2006年。

9. 王安葵、何玉人：《崑曲創作與理論》，瀋陽：春風文藝出版社，2005年。

courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: From Tradition to Modernity: Selected Readings of 20th Century Chinese Culture
courses.description: The course is designed as a sequel to ARTS1000 (Classics of Chinese Humanities: Selected Readings) by focusing on a number of representative texts by famous Chinese intellectuals and writers. They bear witness to the mental deliberations of a generation—or two generations—caught between the forces of tradition and modernity as they found their way through the thicket of source materials from both Chinese and Western cultural traditions. Each author chooses to confront the legacies of Chinese tradition—literary, cultural, and intellectual—by subjecting them to a new reevaluation from modern perspectives derived from their newly acquired knowledge and/or experience from the West. Their modes of analysis have set a new intellectual and scholarly benchmark for later generations. In short, these texts have become modern “classics” in their own right.
courses.learning_outcomes:
學生透過本科的學習，可以 :

1. 提升文學鑒賞能力

2. 加強語文基礎

3. 增加文化素養
courses.course_syllabus:
Several famous authors from different fields of intellectual endeavor are selected –all from the Republican period. Each is represented by a basic text (BT) that is widely influential, hence designed for required reading. These texts in turn are related and can be compared to other texts produced around the same time (listed as supplementary texts or ST) for recommended reading. Altogether they provide a crucial cultural background against which we can then measure our situation in the present 21st century.

科目將選取數位來自各個不同的知識領域的著名作者，全都是民國時期的知識份子和作家。我們會從每位作者的作品中選取一篇具廣泛影響力的代表作，以此作為學員必讀的基礎文本（BT）。學員將閱讀一系列差不多同時期出版的補充文本（ST），這些文本既與基礎文本相互關連，又可相互對照。總而言之，這些文本共同提供了一個重要的文化背景，我們可以借此衡量自身當下所處的二十一世紀的境況。

Format: The course is designed as public lectures, in which Professor Leo Lee will give detailed interpretations of the texts (both basic and supplementary) and place them in a framework of cultural history. Professor Cheung Lik Kwan will assist him by giving two lectures and conducting additional discussions when necessary. The contents of this new course are not limited to literary texts but rather cover a broader intellectual ground, since we will also attempt to delve into the cultural and social context in which such texts were produced--the reason being that modern Chinese literature has become an integral part of modern Chinese history. As such it provides a natural platform for an interdisciplinary attempt to connect literature to cultural and intellectual history, which has been Professor Lee’s own training and background anyway.

授課形式：我們將本科目設計成公開演講的模式，李歐梵教授會在演講中仔細解釋各個文本（包括基礎文本和補充文本），並將之置於文化史的架構中作深入的探討。張歷君教授會在課堂上協助李教授，在必要時進行延伸討論，並發表兩次演講。這個新科目的內容不限於文學文本，而範圍更廣闊，我們會嘗試探討文本產生的文化和社會背景脈絡，因為中國現代文學已然成為中國現代史不可分割的部份。這種做法也提供了一個把文學和文化及思想史連系起來的跨學科研究嘗試的合適平臺。李教授自身的學術訓練和背景本來就是如此。
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. 導師經常徵詢學生對授課進度、課程設計、教學方式及個人學習的意見，俾能及時調整教學方針。

2. 為學習出現問題的學生提供個別輔導。

3. 利用撰寫論文考慮學生的學習進度。

4. 通過論文撰寫，瞭解學員的整體表現。

5. 通過教學問卷調查，全面瞭解學生對本科教學的意見。
courses.required_readings:
Tentative list of lectures together with basic and supplementary readings (Note: Since most texts are books, only selected chapters will be assigned.)

暫定演講題目及書單（包括基礎文本及補充文本）。（註：由於大多文本是書本，我們只會選取內中部分單章作為指定或輔助讀物。）

1. Introduction: From tradition to modernity: the cultural meaning of the 20th century in China and the world 導論：從傳統到現代：「二十世紀」對中國和世界的文化意義

BT: 李歐梵：〈二十世紀中國歷史與文學的現代性及其問題〉，《李歐梵論中國現代文學》季進編。上海：上海三聯書店，2009。

ST: 王汎森：〈思潮與社會條件——新文化運動中的兩個例子〉，《中國近代思想與學術的譜系》。台北市：聯經出版事業股份有限公司，2003。

2. Liang Qichao: from the country to the world 梁啟超：從國家到世界

BT: 梁啟超：《歐遊心影錄》。《梁啟超遊記：歐遊心影錄；新大陸遊記》。北京：東方出版社，2006。 ST: 梁啟超：《汗漫錄》（夏威夷遊記）。《飲冰室合集‧專集》。上海：中華書局，1936。

ST: 梁啟超：《新大陸遊記》。《梁啟超遊記：歐遊心影錄；新大陸遊記》。北京：東方出版社，2006。 ST: 劉鶚著、嚴薇靑注：《老殘遊記》。臺北：黎明文化事業公司，1985。

3. Hu Shih: The discourse of Literary Revolution as the "Chinese Renaissance" 胡適：作為文藝復興的文學革命論

BT: 胡適（鄒小站等譯）：《中國的文藝復興》。長沙市：湖南人民出版社，1998。 BT: Hu Shih, The Chinese Renaissance. Chicago, Ill.: The University of Chicago press, 1934. ST: 周作人：〈人的文學〉 ，《新青年》，5 卷 6 號，1918 年 12 月 15 日。

ST: 魯迅：〈狂人日記〉，《魯迅全集》（第一卷），北京：人民文學出版社，2005年。

4. Lu Xun: New Literature and Old Tradition

魯迅：新文學與舊傳統

BT: 魯迅：〈吶喊‧自序〉；〈狂人日記〉，《吶喊》，載於《魯迅全集》（第一卷），北京：人民文學出版社，2005。

BT: 魯迅：〈補天〉；〈鑄劍〉，《故事新編》，載於《魯迅全集》（第二卷），北京：人民文學出版社，2005年。

ST: 魯迅：〈魏晉風度與藥及酒之關係〉，《魯迅全集（十六卷本）》第三卷（北京：人民文學出版社，1981），頁501-529。

ST: 魯迅：〈理水〉；〈非攻〉，《故事新編》，載於《魯迅全集》（第二卷），北京：人民文學出版社，2005年。

5. Zhou Zuoren: (Re)discovering a new Chinese literary tradition 周作人：重新發現一個中國文學的新傳統

BT: 周作人講校：《中國新文學的源流》。上海，上海書店，1988。

ST: 魯迅：〈小品文的危機〉，《魯迅全集》（第四卷），北京：人民文學出版社，2005年。 ST: 朱自清：《文藝常談》。北京市：中華書局， 2012。

6. Wen Yiduo: Creating a new mythology 聞一多：創立新神話學

BT: 聞一多：《神話與詩》。北京：古籍出版社，1956。 ST: 茅盾：《中國神話研究》。臺北：新陸書局，1974。

ST: 魯迅：《故事新編》，《魯迅全集》（第二卷），北京：人民文學出版社，2005年。 ST: 沈從文：《邊城》。香港：南華書店，1968。

7. Qu Qubai: Chinese Leftist Intellectual and Buddhism for Human Life

瞿秋白：中國左翼知識份子與人生佛教

BT: 瞿秋白：《餓鄉紀程》；《赤都新史》。《瞿秋白文集（文學編）》（第一卷）。北京：人民文學出版社，1998。 ST: 瞿秋白：〈多餘的話〉，《瞿秋白文集（政治理論編）》（第七卷）。北京：人民出版社，1991。

ST: 梁漱溟：《我的自學小史》。《梁漱溟全集》（第二卷）。濟南：山東人民出版社，1989。 ST: 太虛大師：《太虛自傳》。香港：佛敎慈慧服務中心，1998。

8. Shi Zhecun: Psychoanalysis and the Old Story Retold

施蟄存：心理分析與故事新編

BT: 施蟄存：《將軍底頭》。上海：上海書店，1988。

ST: 李歐梵編選：《上海的狐步舞：新感覺派小說選》。臺北：允晨文化實業股份有限公司，2001。 ST: 吳立昌編；施蟄存序：《精神分析狂潮：佛洛德在中國》。南昌市：江西高校出版社，2009。

9. Zhu Guangqian: Evolving a new aesthetics 朱光潛：建立新美學

BT: 朱光潛：《談美》。香港：三聯書店（香港）有限公司，2003。 ST: 宗白華：《美學散步》。上海：上海人民出版社，1981。

ST: 梁宗岱：《詩與真》。臺北：臺灣商務印書館，1963。

10. Feng Zikai: The Art of Everyday Life

豐子愷：日常生活的藝術

BT: 豐子愷：〈塘栖 〉；〈談自己的畫〉，《豐子愷自述：我這一生》。 北京： 中國青年出版社， 2015。

BT: 豐子愷：〈我畫漫畫〉；〈關於兒童〉；〈藝術的生活〉，《豐子愷美術講堂》。台北：城邦文化事業股份有限公司， 2008年。

ST: 豐子愷：〈為青年說弘一法師〉，《豐子愷自述：我這一生》。 北京市：中國青年出版社， 2015。

11. Hsu Chih-mo: The Development of New Poetry

徐志摩：新詩的開拓

BT: 徐志摩：〈這是一個懦怯的世界〉； 〈翡冷翠的一夜〉； 〈海韻〉， 《中國新文學大系》第八集 （詩集）朱自清編選。上海：上海良友圖書印刷公司，1935。

BT: 徐志摩：〈我所知道的康橋〉，《中國新文學大系》第六集 （散文一集）周作人編選。上海：上海良友圖書印刷公司，1935。

ST: 李歐梵著、王宏志等譯：《中國現代作家浪漫的一代》（北京：新星出版社，2005），第5-8 章。

12. Lin Huiyin and Liang Sicheng: Literature and Architecture

林徽因與梁思成：文學與建築

BT: 林徽因：〈那一晚〉；〈九十九度中〉，《林徽因文集：文學卷》梁從誡編。天津：百花文藝出版社，1999。

BT: 梁思成、林徽因：〈北京——都市計畫的無比傑作〉， 《林徽因的另面人生：泛論古建築之美》 （台北：台灣商務印書館股份有限公司，2005），頁 83-120。

ST: 梁思成著、林洙編：《大拙至美：梁思成最美的文字建築》。 北京：中國青年出版社， 2013）， 第一部分、第二部分。

ST: 岳南：《民國才女林徽因和她的時代》。台北市：聯經出版事業股份有限公司 ，2013。

ST: 費慰梅（Wilma Fairbank）著、曲瑩璞等譯：《梁思成與林徽因：一對探索中國建築史的伴侶》。北京：中國文聯出版公司，1997。

13. Fu Lei: A Humanistic Translator

傅雷：人文精神的翻譯家

BT: 傅雷：「一九六一年」〈二月七日〉;〈二月七日晚〉;〈二月八日晨〉;〈三月二十二日〉，《傅雷家書》傅敏編。 瀋陽：遼寧教育出版社，2004。

BT: 傅雷：〈評張愛玲的小說〉;〈羅曼羅蘭 《約翰‧克利斯朵夫》譯者獻詞〉；〈羅曼羅蘭 《約翰‧克利斯朵夫》譯者弁言〉，《傅雷談藝錄》傅敏編，北京：生活‧讀書‧新知三聯書店，2010。

ST: 傅雷：〈貝多芬的作品及其精神〉， 《傅雷音樂講堂》傅敏編，台北市：三言社，2003。
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Hu Shih, The Chinese Renaissance. Chicago, Ill.: The University of Chicago press, 1934.

2. 太虛大師：《太虛自傳》。香港：佛敎慈慧服務中心，1998。

courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Introduction to Chinese Classics
courses.description: This course aims at illustrating the relationship between Chinese classics texts and Chinese culture. Through discussions of important texts in Confucianism, Daoism and Buddhism, students can gain a deeper understanding of these philosophical schools and the underlying features of Chinese tradition, beliefs and values.
courses.learning_outcomes:
預期修畢本科之後，學員能夠：
1. 理解中國傳統文化精神的特質
2. 掌握中國古代經典的基本思想
3. 學習閱讀經典的方法
4. 對人生價值有所反思，提升個人修養
5. 對自我的身份有深刻的體認

Upon completion of this module, students should be able to:
1. acquire a deeper understanding of the various aspects of Chinese tradition and culture.
2. comprehend the special features of Chinese classic texts.
3. understand the methods to read Chinese classic texts.
4. appreciate the traditional Chinese moral value and applied them to their daily life.
5. recognize and develop the self-identity.
courses.course_syllabus:
Course Syllabus:
1. Introduction：the concept and content of Chinese classics (國學).
2. Texts of Confucianism [mainly Four Books (Great Learning, Doctrine of the Mean)
2. 1 Confucian Analects, Mencius], Classic of Filial Piety and I Ching.]
2. 2 Confucian values and its influences on Chinese culture.
3. Texts of Daoism[mainly Laozi, Zhuangzi
3. 1 Daoistic values and its influences on Chinese culture.
4. Texts of Buddhism [mainly Heart Sutra(心經) and the The Platform Sutra of the Sixth Patriarch (六祖壇經)]
4. 1 Buddhist values and its influences on Chinese culture.

第一講﹕國學概說
「國學」釋義

國學內涵之不同理解
今日言國學的時代意義

第二、三講﹕《易經》哲學
《易經》背景簡介
《易經》《易傳》《易學》的分別
象數易簡介
義理易簡介

第四、五講 ﹕孔子的主脈思想
儒家思想興起的背景
「禮」、「義」、「仁」三者的理論關係
《論語》篇章選講

第六、七講 ﹕孟子的中心思想
《孟子》背景簡介
《孟子》篇章選講
孟子性善論、「良知」說及人禽之辨

第八、九講 ﹕老子《道德經》疏釋
《老子》背景簡介
無為之修養與老子的境界形上學

第九、十講 ﹕《莊子》中心思想
《莊子》背景簡介
《莊子》篇章選講
《逍遙遊》與《齊物論》疏釋

第十一講講﹕佛家基本名相引介
原始佛教
大小乘之別

第十二講 ﹕般若精神
《心經》、《金剛經》釋義
應無所住而生其心

第十三講 ﹕《維摩詰所說經》
煩惱根源的詭譎表達
佛教成佛的構想
courses.feedback_evaluation: 通過教學問卷調查，全面瞭解學生對本科教學的意見。

19. 宋‧普濟：《五燈會元》，北京:中華書局，1984年10月。

courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Introduction to Music and Philosophy
courses.description:
This course introduces music and philosophy as intersecting practices through which human beings give meaning to the world around them. By exploring philosophy through music and music through philosophy from cross-cultural perspectives, the course exposes students to a variety of ways that knowledge, existence, religion, ethics, politics, culture, and sound converge.

Rather than a comprehensive introduction to the fields of philosophy and music, this course uses a topical approach to explore several themes in these fields through discussion of selected musical examples and readings presented within an interdisciplinary framework. No background in music or philosophy is assumed or required.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will:

* Become familiar with a broad range of musical and philosophical traditions from diverse geographical locations and historical eras
* Acquire global perspectives on the arts and humanities, and learn to situate their own perspectives and experiences within a global context
* Develop fundamental critical thinking and research skills—how to read, listen, think, and write critically about music and philosophy
* Cultivate an appreciation of the role of music and philosophy in the development of various forms of human community
* Appreciate the interdisciplinary nature of musicology, philosophy, and humanities in general
courses.course_syllabus:
Unit 1: Classical Traditions of Greece and China
Unit 2: Religion, Music, and Philosophy
Unit 3: Music and Contemporary Thought
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and teaching evaluation survey will be conducted in the second last week of the course. Students are reminded of their responsibility and right to give feedback to facilitate enhancement of the course. Students are also welcome to give feedback to the course teachers at any time in person or through emails.
courses.required_readings:
Students will read selected excerpts from the following works:

Plato. Five Dialogues. Translated by G. M. A. Grube, Hackett Publishing Co., 2002.
Plato. The Republic of Plato. Edited by James Adam, Cambridge University Press, 1963.
Cook, Scott. “‘Yue Ji’ 樂記 -- Record of Music: Introduction, Translation, Notes, and Commentary.” Asian Music, vol. 26, no. 2, Apr. 1995, pp. 1–96.
Feld, Steven. Sound and Sentiment: Birds, Weeping, Poetics, and Song in Kaluli Expression. University of Pennsylvania Press, 1990.
Cassirer, Ernst. The Philosophy of Symbolic Forms. Routledge, 2019.
Levi-Strauss, Claude. “The Structural Study of Myth.” The Journal of American Folklore, vol. 68, no. 270, Oct. 1955, pp. 428–444.
Hildegard of Bingen. Hildegard of Bingen’s Book of Divine Works with Letters and Songs. Edited by Matthew Fox, Bear & Co., 1987.
Aslan, Reza. No God but God: The Origins, Evolution, and Future of Islam. Random House, 2011.
Rūmī, Jalāl al-Dīn. Rumi: In the Arms of the Beloved. Translated by Jonathan Star, Penguin Group, 2008.
Kant, Immanuel. Critique of the Power of Judgment. Edited by Paul Guyer et al., Cambridge University Press, 2009.
Burke, Edmund. Philosophical Inquiry into the Origin of Our Ideas of the Sublime and Beautiful. Simon & Brown, 2018.
Zhao, Tingyang. “A Political World Philosophy in Terms of All-Under-Heaven (Tianxia).” Diogenes, vol. 56, no. 1, Feb. 2009, pp. 5–18.
Lyotard, Jean-François. The Postmodern Condition: A Report on Knowledge. University of Minnesota Press, 1984.

In addition to these texts, in-depth listening and discussion of musical examples will be a core element of the class, and students will be required to listen to assigned musical examples outside of class.

courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Creative Cities and Urban Cultural Life
courses.description:
Creative economy and cultural industries have been considered crucial strategies for driving the urban development of global cities. The dynamic landscape of the global cultural scene, where culture converges with the economy, community, heritage, and innovative technologies, has created an impetus for many cities to adopt innovative approaches in utilising urban spaces and cultural resources, enabling citizens to vividly reimagine their urban and cultural life. These approaches are envisioned as and manifested in the form of the development of large-scale urban regions and city clusters, where major cultural facilities such as museums, art districts, performance venues, and festivals significantly contribute to social well-being and intercultural dialogue.
This course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to explore the interface between culture, urban space, and the economy with an eye towards the radically changing cultural landscape of Hong Kong. By offering students both theoretical knowledge and firsthand field experience, this course examines museums, galleries, and various cultural institutions as exemplary cases of how different forms of cultural activities can be turned into powerhouses of creative synergies and economic growth. By the end of the course, students will have gained insight into the complex relationships between the emerging phenomenon of creative cities and urban cultural life, as well as heritage and Chinese culture.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Explain and apply interdisciplinary approaches that help understand the basic concepts of creative cities.
2. Foster critical analysis skills for assessing cultural contexts that promote urban creativity.
3. Cultivate an attitude of innovation and creativity to challenge assumptions in the expanding fields of urban studies and culture.
4. Present case studies and produce creative works that demonstrate students' perspectives when examining Hong Kong as a creative city.
courses.course_syllabus:
Section I: Understanding Creative City and Culture-Led Urban Development

1. What is a Creative City? The Definition of Culture-Led Urban Development
This session introduces Hong Kong as a creative city and includes a workshop on approaches to city exploration. It delves into field study and creative skills for interpreting the intricacies of the city. Additionally, it involves a discussion of assignments and scheduling for the field trips.

2. Contextualizing Creative Cities: A Global Perspective
This session delves into theories of creative cities, investigating how urban environments evolve as cultural constructs. It will provide students with historical contexts from both Western and Asian perspectives. The aim is to equip students, regardless of their backgrounds, with the foundational knowledge necessary for engaging in critical discussions on the subjects of creative cities.

3. The Current Cultural Policy in Hong Kong and Beyond
This session explores how cultural policies play a pivotal role in facilitating culture-led urban development. By referencing both local and international cultural policies and examining the latest trends in cultural development and cultural tourism, students will gain insights into how policies influence the daily lives of both citizens and tourists.

4. Locating Creative Industries in Hong Kong
This session introduces how creative industries serve as a crucial role for economic growth. Students will explore various case studies in Hong Kong as contributors to
economic value through creativity. In Hong Kong, creative industries are thriving, and this session will offer students an array of examples from Hong Kong and beyond.

Section II: Special Topics in Creative Cities
1. Museums and Art Districts as Flagship Icons
This session delves into the role of museums and art districts as representations of city flagships or icons. It will cover how storytelling, innovative museum interpretations, and immersive interactive technologies can unlock creative potential, promote public wellbeing, and articulate shared values in everyday life.

2. Unveiling Public Art in Vibrant Hong Kong
This session covers critical artistic practices that capture urban changes, utilizing the city and urban space as a medium to reflect modern life, architecture, and creative urban environments. Topics include Hong Kong artists creatively interpreting Hong Kong.

3. Heritage Reimagined: Cultivating Dynamic Creative Hubs
This session studies how cities use heritage preservation as a strategy to build a cultural identity. It will also examine examples of art districts that repurpose old structures to transform remnants of the industrial past into new creative hubs, including place-making projects that intertwine a city's history and tangible and intangible culture.

4. Engaging Communities Creatively
This session explores the role that communities play in shaping creativity and enriching urban experiences. In Hong Kong, there is a growing interest in community-led artistic initiatives, and this session will provide students with a diverse range of examples to study.

5. Digital Horizons: Media and Technology Shaping the Urban Landscape
This session delves into the role of media and technology in shaping the social production of urban spaces. In Hong Kong, the intersection of art, technology, and the
concept of a "smart city" has become a key government initiative. This session will provide students with valuable insights into how sustainable urban development is being integrated with cutting-edge technologies and networks.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
CTE questionnaires
Regular reflection and discussion of teachers
courses.required_readings:
Certeau, Michel De. "General Introduction." In *The Practice of Everyday Life*. University of California Press, Berkeley, US, 2011, pp. xi-xxiv.
Hutton, Thomas A. "Introduction - Cities, the Cultural Economy and Urban Studies." In *Cities and the Cultural Economy*. Routledge, Abingdon, UK, 2016, pp. 1-33.
Jonas, Andrew E. G., et al. "Approaching the City." In *Urban Geography: A Critical Introduction*. John Wiley & Sons, Chichester, UK, 2015, pp. 1-26.
Lefebvre, Henri. "From the City to Urban Society." In *The Urban Revolution*. University of Minnesota Press, Minneapolis, US, 2011, pp. 1-22.
Smith, Neil. "New Globalism, New Urbanism: Gentrification as Global Urban Strategy." *Antipode*, vol. 34, no. 3, July 2002, pp. 427-450. https://doi.org/10.1111/1467-8330.00249.

courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Take on Hong Kong: The Revitalisation and Interpretation of Hong Kong's Cultural Heritage
courses.description: This course explores cultural heritage definitions and relevant conceptualisations in the local context. It introduces the historical development of cultural heritage in the contemporary world. It then further discusses the current legal and policy framework of local heritage selection and conservation. It requires the students to reflect on what heritage is and how heritage shall be selected and defined. Through various local case studies, students will explore the social relation between cultural heritage and the local community. They will debate how cultural heritage shall be interpreted from a local perspective but could be operated sustainably.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will understand the basic concepts of cultural heritage.
2. Students will briefly understand the current cultural heritage conservation policy development in Hong Kong.
3. Students will know how cultural heritage could be connected with the local community.
4. Students will understand the importance of cultural heritage conservation and the diversity of cultural heritage interpretation.
courses.course_syllabus:
Section 1: Concepts and theories related to cultural heritage and museum
The concepts and definitions of cultural heritage and its historical evolution.
International conventions related to heritage conservation and management.
The development of Hong Kong's public and private museums and their social roles in education and public engagement in the context of Hong Kong.

Section 2: The historical evolution of the historical structures conservation system in Hong Kong

1. The transformation of Hong Kong’s conservation system of historic structures.
2. The social functions of cultural heritage: the challenges and opportunities of revitalising Hong Kong’s historic structures.
3. Cultural heritage and the construction of local communities: the reuse and revitalisation of cultural heritage and its social connection with local communities.
4. The conservation and sustainable inheritance of Hong Kong's intangible cultural heritage.
courses.required_readings:
Barber, L. (2014). (Re)Making Heritage Policy in Hong Kong: A Relational Politics of Global Knowledge and Local Innovation. Urban Studies (Edinburgh, Scotland), 51(6), 1179–1195.
Cheung. W..L. (2009). Urban transformation of Central District : as a place of living. Conservancy Association Centre for Heritage.
Henderson, J. C. (2008). Conserving Hong Kong’s Heritage: The Case of Queen’s Pier. International Journal of Heritage Studies : IJHS, 14(6), 540–554.
Ho, E. (2022). Heterotopic Heritage in Hong Kong: Tai Kwun and Neo-Victorian Carceral Space. Humanities (Basel), 11(1), 12.
Lu, T. L. -. (2009). Heritage conservation in postcolonial Hong Kong. International Journal of Heritage Studies, 15(2), 258-272.
Lu, T. L.-D. (2016). Empowerment, transformation and the construction of “urban heritage” in post-colonial Hong Kong. International Journal of Heritage Studies : IJHS, 22(4), 325–335.
Nicolson, K. (2016). Landscapes lost and found : appreciating Hong Kong’s heritage cultural landscapes. Hong Kong University Press.
Foster, M. D., & Gilman, L. (2015). UNESCO on the ground : local perspectives on intangible cultural heritage (M. D. Foster & L. Gilman, Eds.). Indiana University Press.
Tsui, P. (2022). Hong Kong heritage : a collection of intangible cultural heritage photography (First edition.). Eastpro Limited.
courses.recommended_readings:
Cheung, S. C. H., & Chau, H. (2013). International Conference on Foodways and Heritage : a perspective of safeguarding the intangible cultural heritage (S. C. H. Cheung & H. Chau, Eds.). [Hong Kong Heritage Museum].
Harrison, R. (2012). Heritage: Critical approaches. London: Routledge.
Matsuda, A., & Mengoni, E. (2016). Introduction: Reconsidering cultural heritage in East Asia. In A. Matsuda, & E. Mengoni (Eds.), Reconsidering cultural heritage in East Asia (pp. 31-46). London: Ubiquity Press.

courses.description: This course explores the applications of Large Language Models (LLMs) in language-related disciplines, including linguistics, translation, language learning, and academic writing. Students will gain hands-on experience in utilizing LLMs for research and practical tasks through Python programming. No prior knowledge of programming is required.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the architecture and applications of LLMs.
2. Develop skills to access and fine-tune LLMs for language-related tasks.
3. Evaluate the linguistic and societal implications of LLMs.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence and Large Language Models (LLMs)
Week 2: Understanding the Architecture and Training of LLMs
Week 3: Python Basics for Accessing LLMs
Week 4: Accessing and Utilizing LLMs with Python (workshop)
Week 5: LLMs in Language Learning and Teaching
Week 6: LLMs for Language Assessment and Evaluation
Week 7: LLMs in Translation and Interpretation
Week 8: Using LLMs in pedagogical research and translation/interpreting (workshop)
Week 9: LLMs for Linguistic Research
Week 10: Using LLMs for Linguistic Research (workshop)
Week 11: Cognitive and Neurological Perspectives on LLMs
Week 12: Interpretability for LLMs
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Homework or assignment: Detailed written feedback on Python code qualty, task completion, and ethical analysis.
Project: Instructor feedback on creatvity, technical execution, and ethical considerations.
Presentation: Oral and written feedback on clarity, depth of analysis and engagement.
courses.required_readings: Introduction to LLMs in Python (Data Camps, free for CUHK students) https://app.datacamp.com/learn/courses/introduction-to-llms-in-python
courses.recommended_readings: Rai, D., Zhou, Y., Feng, S., Saparov, A., & Yao, Z. (2024). A practical review of mechanistic interpretability for transformer-based language models. arXiv preprint arXiv:2407.02646.

courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Reconnections: Studying China across humanistic disciplines
courses.description:
The state of humanities in academia the world over is in crisis. Part of the crisis is caused by global trends toward financial and technological capitalism, but the other part of the problem has to be sought in the humanistic disciplines themselves. Over-specialization in research, fragmentation among and within disciplines, the pressure of utilitarian goals (such as grant-getting for faculty promotion and practical job-orientation for students) are but some of the manifestations obvious to all. How to remedy the situation? Short of an institutional overhaul, we might begin from our own academic base, humanities departments under the Faculty of Arts.

From an academic point of view, over-specialization in the humanities departments results in scholars working in narrow and isolated fields without interaction with colleagues in other departments and fields. The study of China also suffers from such an academic trend, which results in fragmentary studies of narrowly defined topics that fail to connect with each other and with the larger background. A further problem, particularly evident in some humanities fields, is the over-reliance on Western theory, which is applied to Chinese data without reflection or mediation. Certain theoretical excesses, as exemplified in the work of Michel Foucault and other poststructuralist theorists, have led to a general distrust of the human subject itself. Indeed, even the word “humanities” has lost its meaning.

This seminar is designed to explore new ways of making “connections” or “reconnections” across various disciplines and theoretical domains, it is broadly-based by design and all-inclusive in content. It is also intended to serve as a general forum for faculty-student discussion so as to provide a stimulus for humanistic scholarship and future research.
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course, students are provided a rare opportunity to experience the intellectual excitement in a forum-like scholarly atmosphere. The array of topics will expose them to the need to cross narrow disciplinary boundaries. At the very least, they will have a sense of the underlying methodologies and assumptions of different disciplines in the humanities. This will in turn stimulate their own interest in interdisciplinary studies and help them identify topics for their own MPhil and Ph. D research.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course is organized in three parts. The first part will consist of eight lectures, which represent the teacher's own thinking on “inter-disciplinarity” in theory and method as well as the teacher's reading interests and “mini-research” projects. They are mostly exploratory in nature and do not altogether constitute a cohesive scheme. The topics stem from a background in literature, history, and cultural studies, with side forays into anthropology, music, film and architecture.
1 Introduction: Crossing boundaries and making connections
2 Mediating connections: theory, criticism, comparison
3 “Unexpected affinities”: Sima Qian’s (司馬遷) Xiangyu (項羽) vs. Homer’s Achilles as heroic tropes
4 Cultural Filiations: Vico and Zhu Gungqian (朱光潛)
5 Literary modernity: The lyrical and the Epic in China and Europe
6 Changing imaginaries of space: China and the World
7 Lu Xun (魯迅) and “Specters” (with a glance at Walter Benjamin)

The second part of the course will be guest presentations organized into four thematic groups :
1. history, religion and anthropology
2. language, philosophy and translation
3. music and visual culture
4. leftwing cosmopolitanism in the 1930s.

The final part of the seminar will consist of reports by registered postgraduate students, preferably Ph.D. and MPhil candidates, on a topic related to their proposed research that can benefit from such an inter-disciplinary forum.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Form
2. Students' comments and feedbacks solicited throughout the course via email, moodle, and personal meeting.
3. Students' assignments (a short reserach proposal and a final paper), by which the learning outcomes are assessed
courses.required_readings:
Week 1 Introduction: Crossing boundaries and making connections
余英時 “試論中國人文研究的再出發”in his 文史傳統與文化重建 （北京：三聯， 2004）， 510－544
Joe Moran, Interdisciplinarity (London: Routledge, 2002), chapters 2-5
Umberto Eco, Serendipities: Language and Lunacy (NY: Harcourt Brace, 1999), chapters 2-3

Weeks 2-3 Mediating connections: theory, criticism, comparison
Edward Said, The World, the Text, and the Critic (Cambridge, Ma.: Harvard Univ. Press, 1983), Chapter 1 (“Secular Criticism”) 10 (“Traveling Theory”); also included in Moustafa Bayoumi and Andrew Rubin eds., The Edward Said Reader (New York: Vintage Books, 2000),195-242
Rey Chow ed., Modern Chinese Literary and Cultural Studies in the Age of Theory (Durham: Duke Univ. Press, 2000), 1-25 (Introduction)
Hayden White, Tropics of Discourse: Essays in Cultural Criticism (Baltimore: Johns Hopkins Univ. Press, 1985), chapter 5 (“The Fictions of Factual Representation)

Week 4 “Unexpected affinities”: Sima Qian’s (司馬遷) Xiangyu (項羽) vs. Homer’s Achilles as heroic tropes
司馬遷 史紀：“項羽本紀”
Homer, The Iliad, tr. Richard Lattimore (Chicago: Univ. of Chicago Press, 1961), Books 18, 22, 24
Mu-chou Poo, “The Cultural Construction of Hero (ying-xiong) in Chinese History,” in Susan Browneill ed., From Athens to Beijing: West Meets East in the Olympic Games, Vol. 1 Sport, the Body, and Humanism in Ancient Greece and China (New York: Greekworks.com, 2011), 123-135.

Week 5 Cultural Filiations: Vico and Zhu Gungqian (朱光潛)
Giambattista Vico, New Science, tr. David Marsh (London: Penguin Books, 2001), 1-31 (Introduction by Anthony Grafton; “Idea of the Work”
Edward Said, Humanism and Democratic Criticism (New York: Columbia Univ. Press, 2004), Chapters 3-4 (“The Return to Philology”; “Introduction to Erich Auerbach’s Mimesis”)
維柯 (朱光潛譯)， 新科學 (北京： 人民文學出版社， 1986;2008), 574-575 (中譯者後記)，576－631 （維科自傳）
朱光潛 維科的新科學及其對中西美學的影響 （香港： 中文大學出版社, 1984), 1－98

Week 6 Literary modernity: The lyrical and the Epic in China and Europe
Jaroslav Prusek, The Lyrical and the Epic: Studies in Modern Chinese Literature, ed. Leo Ou-fan Lee (Bloomington, Ind.: Indiana Univ. Press, 1980), Foreword, chapters 1, 3
王德威 抒情傳統與中國現代性 （北京： 三聯， 2010），pp. 3—68
劉鶚 老殘遊記 , 1－10 回

Week 7: Changing imaginaries of space: China and the World
葛兆光 宅茲中國 （北京： 中華書局， 2011， pp. 39-131
Wang Hui (Theodore Huters ed.), The Politics of Imagining Asia (Cambridge, Ma.: Harvard Univ. Press, 2011), Chapter 2 (“How to Explain China and Its Modernity”)

Week 8. Lu Xun (魯迅) and “Specters” (with a glance at Walter Benjamin)
魯迅 朝華夕拾； 野草
丸尾常喜 （tr. 秦弓） 人與鬼的糾葛—魯迅小說論析 （北京：人民文學出版社， 1995，pp. 1-36, 84-170, 251-314
courses.recommended_readings:
Week 1 Introduction: Crossing boundaries and making connections
Jerome Kagan, The Three Cultures: Natural Sciences, Social Sciences, and the Humanities in the 21st Century (Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Press, 2009), chapter 1

Weeks 2-3 Mediating connections: theory, criticism, comparison
Terry Eagleton, After Theory (London: Penguin Books, 2004), entire
Haun Saussy ed., Comparative Literature in the Age of Globalization (Baltimore: Johns Hopkins Press, 2006), 3-62, 230-236 (Articles by Saussy, Damrosch, Apter, and Zhang Longxi)
Peter Burke, What is Cultural History? (Cambridge, UK: Polity, 2008), chapters 3-4 (“The moment of Historical Anthropology”; “A New Paradigm?)

Week 4 “Unexpected affinities”: Sima Qian’s (司馬遷) Xiangyu (項羽) vs. Homer’s Achilles as heroic tropes
Zhang Longxi, Unexpected Affinities: Reading across Cultures (Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 2007), Chapters 1-2
Stephen W. Durrant, The Cloudy Mirror: Tension and Conflict in the Writings of Sima Qian (Albany, NY: State Univ. of New York Press, 1995), 124-143 (“Ideologue versus Narrator)

Week 5 Cultural Filiations: Vico and Zhu Gungqian (朱光潛)
Hayden White, Tropics of Discourse, chapters 9,10 (on Vico’s New Science and Croce’s criticism of Vico)
Paul Bove, Poetry against Torture: Criticism, History, and the Human (Hong Kong: Hong Kong Univ. Press, 2008), Chapter 1-2 (“Vico and Philological Criticism,” “The Case against Descartes”))

Week 6 Literary modernity: The lyrical and the Epic in China and Europe
Ralph Freedman, The Lyrical Novel: Studies in Hermann Hesse, Andre Gide, and Virginia Woolf (Princeton: Princeton Univ. Press, 1963), Chapters 1-2
Franco Moretti, Modern Epic: The World System from Goethe to Garcia Marquez (London & NY: Verso, 1997), Chapter on Joyce’s Ulysses

Week 7: Changing imaginaries of space: China and the World
Yi-Fu Tuan, Space and Place: The Perspective of Experience (Minneapolis: Univ. of Minnesota Press, 1977), Chapters 2,5,8,9
漢寶德 中國德建築與文化 （台北： 聯經， 2002), pp. 8-31, 58-135
吳趼人, 新石頭記 (part 2)
Theodore Huters, Bringing the World Home: Approaching the West in Late Qing and Early Republican China (Honolulu: Univ. of Hawaii Press, 2005), Chapters 6, 7

Week 8. Lu Xun (魯迅) and “Specters” (with a glance at Walter Benjamin)
Walter Benjamin s (tr. Harry Zohn), Illuminations (New York: Schocken Books, 1969), Essays on Kafka and “Theses on the Philosophy of History”)
Walter Benjamin (tr. Edmund Jephcott), Reflections (New York: Schocken Books, 1986), Part One (“A Berlin Childhood,” “One-Way Street”)[Chinese translation available]

courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Advanced Studies in the Humanities
courses.description:
This course provides an opportunity for students to be exposed to current developments in specific areas of the Humanities. The topics vary according to the research expertise of the staff or visiting academics.

Course content and format is determined by the instructor(s).

Students are allowed to take the above course more than once and gain the units each time they pass the course. However, students cannot take courses with the same course code more than once in a single term.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Research Postgraduate Programmes under Faculty of Arts
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire critical familiarity with the issues discussed.
2. Analyze and critically interpret some significant primary texts in the Humanities chosen by the course instructor.
courses.course_syllabus: The syllabus and assessment type may vary according to the teaching staff and the topic selected. Please refer to the course outline for details.
courses.feedback_evaluation: To be provided by the instructor concerned.
courses.required_readings: To be provided by the instructor concerned. The reading list varies depending of the course teacher and the topics selected.
courses.recommended_readings: To be provided by the instructor concerned. The reading list varies depending of the course teacher and the topics selected.

courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Performing Public Humanities
courses.description:
Performing Public Humanities explores the ongoing questions and stakes of cultivating a public-facing humanities today, with a focus on performance as advocacy and action. As such, this course examines public humanities through performance, and simultaneously highlights the work of universities and cultural nonprofits across a variety of contexts, collaborations, and communities. RPg students come together for co-creative research that crisscrosses performance and public human inquiry, with the aim of fostering socially engaged thinking that cuts across disciplinary modes of interrogation.
This course does not require prior performing experience or knowledge.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students enrolled in Research Postgraduate Programmes in the Faculty of Arts.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students who complete this course will be able to:

* Initiate and lead discussions about cultivating a public-facing humanities today.
* Examine public human inquiry through multiple understandings and perspectives of performance.
* Foster and facilitate socially engaged thinking in and across universities and cultural nonprofits.
courses.course_syllabus:
I. Contexts

1. “Public humanities”: current approaches, theories, praxes
2. “Performance” as advocacy and action
3. “Social engagement” across disciplines and practices
4. Performing public human inquiry: student-led seminar I

II. Collaborations

1. Performing public humanities: collaborations and divergence
2. Themed debate, based on assigned readings and prepared case studies focusing on universities and cultural nonprofits
3. Experiential activity: participating and observing an open rehearsal of an LGBTQ+ voice ensemble or another local civic musical group
4. Performing public human inquiry: student-led seminar II

III. Communities

1. Performing public humanities: communities and individuals
2. Themed debate, based on assigned readings and prepared case studies focusing on universities and cultural nonprofits
3. Experiential activity: co-curating a grassroot outreach program
4. Performing public human inquiry: student-led seminar III
courses.feedback_evaluation: There will be a midterm survey and an official CTE towards the end of the course. Your feedback is vital and anonymous; I encourage you to participate and give comments. Please also feel free to contact me in person or by email at any point during the course.
courses.required_readings:
Bate, Jonathan, ed. 2014. *The Public Value of the Humanities*. London: Bloomsbury.
Conquergood, Dwight. 2013. “Beyond the Text: Toward a Performative Cultural Politics.” In *Cultural Struggles: Performance, Ethnography, Praxis* (edited and with a critical introduction by E. Patrick Johnson), 47–63. Ann Arbor, MI: University of Michigan Press.
Knowles, Ric. 2017. *Performing the Intercultural City*. Ann Arbor, MI: University of Michigan Press.
Kondo, Dorinne. 2018. *Worldmaking: Race, Performance, and the Work of Creativity*. Durham, NC: Duke University Press.
Leonard, Sophia, Benjamin Reiss, Víctor Velázquez Antonio, and Makenzie Renee Fitzgerald. 2020. “Public Humanities in the Reconstructed University.” American Literature 92, no. 4: 781–790.
MacLachlan, Heather. 2020. *Singing Out: GALA Choruses and Social Change*. Ann Arbor, MI: University of Michigan Press.
Rai, Shirin M., Milija Gluhovic, Silvija Jestrovic, and Michael Saward, ed. 2021. *The Oxford Handbook of Politics and Performance*. New York: Oxford University Press.
Smulyan, Susan, ed. 2020. *Doing Public Humanities*. London: Routledge.
- ---------. 2022. “Why Public Humanities?” *Daedalus* 151, no. 3 (Summer): 124–137.
Sommer, Doris. 2014. *The Work of Art in the World: Civic Agency and Public Humanities*. Durham, NC: Duke University Press.
courses.recommended_readings:
André, Naomi. 2018. *Black Opera: History, Power, Engagement*. Champaign, IL: University of Illinois Press.
Berkowitz, Carin, and Matthew Gibson. 2022. “Reframing the Public Humanities: The Tensions, Challenges & Potentials of a More Expansive Endeavor.” Daedalus 151, no. 3 (Summer): 68–81.
Brooks, Peter, and Hilary Jewett, ed. 2014. *The Humanities and Public Life*. New York: Fordham University Press.
Fauser, Annegret, and Michael A. Figueroa, ed. 2020. *Performing Commemoration: Musical Reenactment and the Politics of Trauma.* Ann Arbor, MI: University of Michigan Press.
Hahn, Tomie. 2021. *Arousing Sense: Recipes for Workshopping Sensory Experience*. Champaign, IL: University of Illinois Press.
Krmpotich, Cara. 2016. “Public Humanities as Third Space: Memory, Meaning-Making and Collections and the Enunciation of ‘We’ in Research.” University of Toronto Quarterly 85, no. 4 (Fall): 82–92.
Looser, Diana. 2021. *Moving Islands: Contemporary Performance and the Global Pacific*. Ann Arbor, MI: University of Michigan Press.
Mullen, Mary L. 2016. “Public Humanities’ (Victorian) Culture Problem.” Cultural Studies 30, no. 2: 183–204.
Overend, David. 2023. *Performance in the Field: Interdisciplinary Practice-as-Research*. Cham: Palgrave Macmillan.
Schwan, Anne, and Tara Thomson, ed. 2022. *The Palgrave Handbook of Digital and Public Humanities*. Cham: Palgrave Macmillan.

courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Digital Methods for Humanities Research
courses.description: The use of digital methods in research is growing rapidly in many fields in the humanities from China Studies to archaeology. This course introduces students to the exciting world of digital humanities, including text mining (text), digital analysis of images (image), and 3-D scanning and printing (object). These are skills that can be used to gain insights from texts written in Chinese, English and other languages, paintings, engravings or statuary, as well as historical artefacts. Students will be able to apply what they learn in this course to a range of questions in the humanities. It will also be useful in a variety of future careers in both the academic and applied humanities. This is an introductory postgraduate course and no background in digital humanities is required. The class will meet in the Digital Scholarship Lab of the University Library and will culminate in a group project (website) that students can add to their portfolios.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students enrolled in Research Postgraduate Programmes in the Faculty of Arts.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Reflect on the role of digital methods in humanities research
2. Leverage the latest tools developed around the world and the resources available at CUHK for digital humanities research
3. Learn a range of digital methods for humanities research applicable to a variety of fields (word-image-object), including specific computational methods borrowed from data science
4. Apply those methods to specific humanities questions and assess their success
5. Collaborate with other students to create a final project that leverages these methods
courses.course_syllabus:
1. What is Digital Humanities?
2. Do the Humanities have Data?
3. Interacting with Computers: Python Made Easy
4. Word: Text Mining with CText I (Chinese)
5. Word: Text Mining with CText II (Chinese)
6. Word: NLP with CText (Chinese & English)
7. Word: More NLP with Python (English & other languages)
8. Image: Image Processing (Filters and Edge Detection)
9. Image: Recognizing Images (Image Analysis)
10. Image: Digital Art History in Action (Giuseppe Castiglione case study)
11. Object: 3D Scanning
12. Object: 3D Printing I
13. Object: 3D Printing II
14. Reflections & Final Project Troubleshooting
courses.required_readings:
Mattingly, William. Introduction to Python for Humanists. Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press, 2023.
Arnold, Taylor, and Lauren Tilton. Distant Viewing : Computational Exploration of Digital Images. Cambridge, Massachusetts: The MIT Press, 2023. Print.
Kumar, L. Jyothish., Pulak M. Pandey, and David Ian. Wimpenny, eds. 3D Printing and Additive Manufacturing Technologies. 1st ed. 2019. Singapore: Springer Singapore, 2019. Print.
courses.recommended_readings:
Manovich, Lev. Cultural Analytics. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press, 2018.
Nyhan, Julianne., and Marco. Passarotti, eds. One Origin of Digital Humanities : Fr Roberto Busa in His Own Words. 1st ed. 2019. Cham: Springer International Publishing, 2019. Print.
Guldi, Jo. The Dangerous Art of Text Mining : A Methodology for Digital History. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2023.
Sturgeon, Donald. “Chinese Text Project: A Dynamic Digital Library of Premodern Chinese.” Digital Scholarship in the Humanities 36.Supplement\_1 (2021): i101–i112.
Nature Special Issue, Computational Social Sciences: https://www.nature.com/collections/cadaddgige
